India and Pakistan have shared a
troubled relationship since 1947. That's
the year of partition. Since then, both
India and Pakistan have fought multiple
wars. But when it comes to Islamabad,
old habits die hard, thus rendering past
talks pretty much meaningless and
leaving the prospect of peace rather
elusive. In October 1947, the first war
over Kashmir broke out and continued
until 1948 when Kashmir was divided.
Eventually failed talks led to a second
war in 1960s which is also when India
and Pakistan signed the Indis waters
treaty in 1963. Talks were held once
again over the disputed territory of
Kashmir mediated by the US and the UK.
However, no agreement was reached even
then. In 1965, the two countries fought
the second war over Kashmir. One which
ended inconclusively with a ceasefire.
In 1971, the Indian army's involvement
in the Bangladesh liberation war
culminated in the similar agreement in
1972 where both sides agreed to settle
any disputes by peaceful means. There
have been many more rounds of talks
after that all with limited success
because they were thwarted each time by
repeated acts of terror and crossber
violations by Pakistan. And not just
that, the fact that the peace talks did
not materialize is evident in the spate
of terror attacks that ensued such as
the December 2001 attack on the Indian
Parliament in New Delhi that killed 14
people. Then in November 2008, armed
gunmen opened fire on civilians at
several sites in Mumbai, killing over
150. Even as trade relations began to
improve across the LOC and more
recently, talks were also initiated in
the aftermath of the 2016 Uri attacks
and Pulwama attacks in 2019. But
unfortunately, not to much avail. And
finally, the Pelgam terror attack on the
22nd of April this year, which capped
all previous attacks for its mode of
warfare. A dastardly attack on civilians
and a clear message to India that
Islamabad never did and perhaps never
will roll back its terror machine. Now,

that his country's armed forces were
